citations.narrative:
In several enclosures, there were potential hazards for the animals contained in the enclosure that could result in injuries.
In hill pen 2, where the cape buffalo was housed, there were metal fenceposts and rebar extending 1 foot vertically out of
a retaining wall near the entrance to the enclosure, at chest height for the animal. According to the facility, the record rain
washed away the dirt and rocks in the retaining wall exposing the pipes. In Addax/Addra there was a pvc irrigation pipe
exposed across a ravine, creating a potential entrapment hazard. In the gerenuk enclosure, there was hardware wire with
sharp points at face height for the animals. In PB08, on the door of the barbary sheep enclosure, the fence was no longer
in good repair and had sharp points.
Facilities must be structurally sound, constructed with material that is an appropriate strength for the animals involved and
shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injuries and contain the animals.
Corrected during inspection.

The perimeter fences and additional security methods in place were not sufficient to keep mountain lion from entering the
facility and predating on four ungulates. The facility is located within the native habitat range for mountain lions and staff
have successfully handled incursions by a different mountain lion through nonlethal mitigation measures that were
effective preventing predation in the past. Despite these measures being in place, on February 2, 2023 a mountain lion
entered the facility and predated one peninsular pronghorn. Although the facility staff quickly sought to prevent additional
losses by implementing additional methods to prevent predation, during the next sixty-six (66) hour period the same
mountain lion entered the facility at least three additional times and predated three additional animals (two East African
Sitatunga and one Zambezi Lechwe). Following the last predation event, the facility was issued a state permit to allow for
the implementation of non-lethal mitigation/deterrence methods. Since this time, the facility has partnered with local
experts in wildlife biology and the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to identify and implement these lawfully
authorized non-lethal deterrents and has successfully prevented additional predation.
All licensees who maintain animals in outdoor housing facilities are required to have a perimeter fence that is constructed
so that it protects animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized people from having contact with the
animals in the facility. Failure to prevent entry of animals such as mountain lions may result in harm to the regulated
animals.
As of the time of inspection, the noncompliance had been corrected by implementing additional methods to prevent the
entry of this mountain lion by adding overnight Wildlife Care Specialists, hotwire, camera traps, surveillance, utilizing other
deterrents, removing cover and attempting to capture the suspected individual mountain lion. No further incidents of
predation have occurred since these methods were introduced.
Corrected at the time of inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Wildlife Care staff.
Additional Inspectors:
AMANDA WHITE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
In several enclosures, there were potential hazards for the animals contained in the enclosure that could result in injuries. 
In hill pen 2, where the cape buffalo was housed, there were metal fenceposts and rebar extending 1 foot vertically out of 
a retaining wall near the entrance to the enclosure, at chest height for the animal. According to the facility, the record rain 
washed away the dirt and rocks in the retaining wall exposing the pipes. In Addax/Addra there was a pvc irrigation pipe 
exposed across a ravine, creating a potential entrapment hazard. In the gerenuk enclosure, there was hardware wire with 
sharp points at face height for the animals. In PB08, on the door of the barbary sheep enclosure, the fence was no longer 
in good repair and had sharp points. 
 
Facilities must be structurally sound, constructed with material that is an appropriate strength for the animals involved and 
shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals from injuries and contain the animals. 
 
Corrected during inspection. 
3.127(d)  Critical
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fences and additional security methods in place were not sufficient to keep mountain lion from entering the 
facility and predating on four ungulates. The facility is located within the native habitat range for mountain lions and staff 
have successfully handled incursions by a different mountain lion through nonlethal mitigation measures that were 
effective preventing predation in the past. Despite these measures being in place, on February 2, 2023 a mountain lion 
entered the facility and predated one peninsular pronghorn. Although the facility staff quickly sought to prevent additional 
losses by implementing additional methods to prevent predation, during the next sixty-six (66) hour period the same 
mountain lion entered the facility at least three additional times and predated three additional animals (two East African 
Sitatunga and one Zambezi Lechwe). Following the last predation event, the facility was issued a state permit to allow for 
the implementation of non-lethal mitigation/deterrence methods. Since this time, the facility has partnered with local 
experts in wildlife biology and the California Department of Fish and Wildlife to identify and implement these lawfully 
authorized non-lethal deterrents and has successfully prevented additional predation.

All licensees who maintain animals in outdoor housing facilities are required to have a perimeter fence that is constructed 
so that it protects animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized people from having contact with the 
animals in the facility. Failure to prevent entry of animals such as mountain lions may result in harm to the regulated 
animals. 
 
As of the time of inspection, the noncompliance had been corrected by implementing additional methods to prevent the 
entry of this mountain lion by adding overnight Wildlife Care Specialists, hotwire, camera traps, surveillance, utilizing other 
deterrents, removing cover and attempting to capture the suspected individual mountain lion. No further incidents of 
predation have occurred since these methods were introduced. 
 
Corrected at the time of inspection. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Wildlife Care staff. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
AMANDA WHITE, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
